text: [MUSIC]
ADI IGNATIUS: Hi.

I want to welcome everybody
to the first episode of HBR
Quarantined.
Thank you for being here.

I'm Adi Ignatius, the editor
chief of Harvard Business
Review.

And my co-host is
Josh Macht, who
heads product and innovation.
Josh, welcome.
JOSHUA MACHT: Thanks, Adi.

It's great to be
kicking off the show.
How are you doing?
ADI IGNATIUS: I'm doing fine.
We've launched this show.

We know that millions
of our followers,

our readers, our
fans, are at home,
have been at home for weeks.

This is week 7 for
us working from home.

So we wanted to create
a program for you

that really gets into the big
issues of the day, COVID-19,

and the fallout, and how
it's affecting business,

how it's affecting
work, how it's

affecting the search for talent,
how it's affecting our lives.

We have a special
guest this week,

Thomas Friedman, the
Pulitzer-Prize-winning

columnist for The New
York Times will be here.

We'll have a conversation
with him in just a moment.

We also are going to
take your questions.

So if you put question
in the comment box,
we will try to get to those.
But Josh, before we start--

I just-- I want
to ask you, week 7

quarantine, how
are you surviving?

How are are you
getting work done?
JOSHUA MACHT: Yeah.

Well, we're getting work
done, which is good.

I mean, we're
definitely adjusting.
It's been a couple of months.

And I mean, it's feeling more
like the marathon part of this

is kicking in, a marathon that
we were never really prepared
to run.
But we're adjusting.
And I don't know.
There are moments.

I had a beer with
someone this weekend.
We were 6, 8 feet apart.

There are moments
where you almost feel
like a new normal or something.
But definitely strange.
What about you, Adi?

What are you-- how
are you keeping sane?

ADI IGNATIUS:
Yeah, it's strange.

I go through cycles,
I guess, emotional.

I mean, in some ways
we've never been busier.

And we are fortunate
enough to be in a business

where we can move remotely
and get most things done.

But it's really
personally what you do.

I mean, my wife and I are
playing gin rummy and keeping

score, and we're up
to 5,000 points I
do 30 crossword puzzles a week.

I am experimenting with
new recipes for squirrel
and neighbor's house cat.

I mean, they're just different
ways that you keep going.

JOSHUA MACHT: You
definitely got me going
on the crossword puzzle thing.

I've actually now
really tried that,
and I am a little bit hooked.

ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah,
it's a great time waste.
JOSHUA MACHT: Yeah.

ADI IGNATIUS: I'll
send you some links.
Just to say quickly, Jimmy.

Josh and I work together
at Time magazine.

Josh was one of the first
editors of the time.com

website, when none
of the rest of us

could figure out what
new world digital was,
he was an early pioneer.

He and I have innovated since
then, tried to bring innovation
to Harvard Business Review.

That's what we're doing today
with a new innovation that we
hope will be useful for people.

They always told us we
should not be on TV.

But I think we may have
found a loophole here,

so we're going to drive a
truck right through that

JOSHUA MACHT: This
is definitely a beta.
There's no question about that.

And we're thankful that
our guest has come along
with us, as well.

But I think we're going to learn
a lot quickly and definitely

hope we have a conversation
that people can be a part of.
ADI IGNATIUS: All right.
So let's get into it.

Before we bring on Tom, I want
to show a quick TikTok clip.

It's sort of a
meme about what it

is when you're working at
home, and maybe your spouse

is not working at home,
and you're both sort
of driving each other crazy.
So Producer Dave, hit that clip.
[HIP-HOP MUSIC]
[MAN SINGING NONSENSE SYLLABLES]
You know, that feeling.

JOSHUA MACHT: He's not-- which
role would you play there, Adi?

For me, that's for Dave
Di Iulio, our producer.
Maybe we can see him too.

ADI IGNATIUS: Say
hi, Producer Dave.
DAVE DI IULLO: Hey, how are you?
JOSHUA MACHT: Hello.
Which role would you be?

DAVE DI IULLO: I think I'd
be the one in the fat suit,
and I wouldn't need a costume.
ADI IGNATIUS: This is funny.
The trope that we--

that the talent
insults the producers.

But you're just jumping right
in and insulting yourself.

DAVE DI IULLO: I'll take
it where I can get it.
ADI IGNATIUS: All right.

So let's let let's
get our conversation.

We have Tom Friedman
waiting to join us.

And there's a lot
we want to ask him.

Again, if you have
questions for Tom as well,
put them in the comment box.
But Tom, let's start.
What is your life like now?

How are you-- we think of you as
a globe-trotting correspondent.
How-- what's your life like now?
Where are you?

How are you able to
get your work done?

THOMAS FRIEDMAN:
Well, our bureau--

I work out of the Washington
bureau, normally, Adi.
And Josh, hi to you.

And great to be with
you guys, first of all.
JOSHUA MACHT: Thank you.

THOMAS FRIEDMAN: So
I normally work out
of the Washington bureau.

We've been closed for
basically two months now.

So I've been
working at our home,
out of our home in Bethesda.

And I kind of go to
work every morning

by coming to my front corner
of the house and office.
And my wife Ann goes to hers.

Some people may know
my wife was just

about to open a new museum
in Washington called

Planet Word to promote reading,
literacy, and love of language.
We were supposed to open May 31.

So she's been scrambling to
deal with those adjustments
for Planet Word.

And for me I made the adjustment
easily because through Zoom,

and through Skype, and through
LinkedIn and these systems,

I can have conversations with
people all over the world.

I'm doing webinars tomorrow
with some UN Ambassadors,

a group in India, and a group
in China, all in one day.

And the amount of travel
that would have taken
is staggering to think about.
It's not as good.

It's about 85% as good, but
it's 100% less stressful on me.
So I'm appreciating that.

After work we always
have dinner together.

Occasionally, do
take out from some

of our favorite restaurants
to help them out.

And then every night,
we watch an episode

of Gilmore Girls, which is the
show that my girls grew up on.

It has seven seasons,
22 episodes each season.
We're deep into season 2 now.

And it's a wonderful
show, if you

haven't seen it,
about relationships,
love, small-town values.

And it's the best
antidote to COVID-19.

JOSHUA MACHT: We can
have a whole show just
talking about that, had I known.

But we have so much [INAUDIBLE],,
tell me, that's perfect.

ADI IGNATIUS: So if
you just joined us,

this is HBR Quarantine, brought
to you by Gilmore Girls.
That's right, Gilmore Girls.
Let's show them some love.
Well, so that's interesting.

So obviously, most
people or many people,
are not able to work from home.

And it kind of underlines some
of the inequalities of life

but inequalities that are
exacerbated at the moment.

Before I get to that,
though let's focus then

on this life, the life that you
lead, the life that we lead,

the life that a lot of
white collar people lead.
Do we need to be in the office?

I mean, is this sort of
calling BS on the notion

that we actually need to be
present to get work done?

THOMAS FRIEDMAN:
Well, I'll tell you,

Adi, I really enjoy being in the
newsroom in The New York Times.

So I'm in the back corner
of the Washington bureau,

with my friend and
colleague, Maureen Dowd.

But all around us in a kind of
horse shoe are the reporters.

And I love walking around,
talking to reporters.
I'm still a newsroom rat.
I started as a reporter.
I'm still a reporter at heart.
And so I do miss that.

Not that I can't call people
on the phone or whatnot,

but I like being in the company
of news people in newsrooms.

Obviously, I miss
going, touching,

feeling, and the
serendipitous things
that happen when you travel.

But even in the best of
days, I worked at home
probably 50% of the time.

And I found a quiet place to
work, use the phone, et cetera.

So for me, that part isn't
that big a deprivation.

JOSHUA MACHT: I'm curious, Tom,
because you were pretty early

on with your column
talking about the balance

of physical health
versus economic health.

I thought it was
really interesting

that you did some
things on Sandel, early
on Professor Sandel's thought.
All that was great.
And I just wonder how you're--

and even today, you're
talking about it.

So I just wonder how your
thoughts of that are evolving.

THOMAS FRIEDMAN: So yeah, I
helped kick off that debate.

It was really, I would say, The
Wall Street Journal editorial
on Friday.

And then myself and Dr. David
Katz on Saturday and Sunday

really kicked this off of
how do we find the right

balance between saving lives
and saving livelihoods?

Because there's a
lot of ways to die.

You can die by
COVID-19, and you can

die at depth of utter
despair from having

lost your life savings,
your job, your business.
And we need to balance both.

We need to-- the goal needs
to be total harm minimization.

And that's been my theme
from the very beginning.

The debate-- it took about
a couple of weeks, Josh.

And then the debate
just exploded.
And now it's everywhere.

And I've basically used
my time between then

and now to really
drill down on what

I found to be the most
helpful, thoughtful people
in that discussion.

So I can really perfect, from
my point of view, what I think,
how I think about this.

And if you look at
the world today, Josh,

you really see there are kind of
three basic models, out there.
The first is the Swedish model.

They don't like to spell
it out in so many words,

but Sweden opted
for herd immunity.

Now, let me just take a step
back and just to remind people

that there's only one way that
nature has given us to resist

a pandemic virus, and that's by
triggering our immune system,

that nature gave us
an immune system.

And there's only two ways
to develop immunity--

either a vaccine, where
we do it medically,

or we do it organically by
developing the antibodies,

by having the disease and
developing the antibodies

in order to become
immune from it.

So Sweden basically said, we're
going to go for herd immunity.

We're not going to shut down our
malls, shops, and restaurants.

We're going to tell people to
limit their gatherings to 50

people, and we're going to
do our best to quarantine

and protect the elderly,
the most vulnerable,
and the most immune compromised.

And we're basically going
to let the disease go
through the population.

And those who either
get it and become immune

and get it and do not
require hospitalization

they are betting will be, less
than the number of hospital
beds in the country.
That's their bet.
And it's playing out.

It's way too soon to
say, categorically,
one way or another.

But I get up every morning,
and the first thing I click on
is Sweden.
Then I click on bet number two.

I click on Singapore,
Australia, New Zealand, China.

They're various iterations
of bet number two.

Bet number two is super
efficient suppression

and mitigation, with super
efficient tracing, tracking,
and sequestering--

super efficient at
the Chinese end, where

they don't have to worry
about civil liberties,

and just efficient
at the New Zealand,
Australia, Singapore end.
And we see how they're doing.

And what you see are various
degrees of challenge there.

New Zealand and Australia
basically are saying,
we have completely suppressed.
There's no new cases.

And my god, hats off
to them for that.

But let's just
remember, they're doing

that while keeping
their countries
completely sealed off.
All right.

And China, they have brought
the new cases down to near zero
in Wuhan and in other places.

But they're doing that with
incredibly intrusive tracking,
tracing.
I take your temperature.
I test you.
You've got the disease.
You're not going home.

You're going to a clinic,
and for 14 days, et cetera.
So that's model number two.
Model number three is Georgia.

It's the United
States of America.

It's I'm tired of
sitting at home.
I'm going to take my chances.

One day maybe we'll catch
up with tracking, tracing

and quarantine, but we're just
going to do it our own way.

And I would tell you, I'm very
worried about that approach

because if there's one
thing I've learned--

and I learned this
from David Katz,

which is that if you don't
respect this disease,

it will kill either you
or someone you love.
And so be very careful.
So those are the three models.

And I get up every
morning, and I
see which model is doing best.

ADI IGNATIUS: So
again, we're here

with Tom Friedman of
The New York Times.

If you have questions that
you would like to post to him,

put them in the comment box, and
we'll try to get it to as many
as we can of those soon.
You know, Tom.

I read something like
VW has said on May 3

it's going to open an
auto plant in Chattanooga.
I think it's 3,800 employees.
Is that nuts?

THOMAS FRIEDMAN: Well,
let me go to 30,000
feet for a second, Adi.

Because one of the things
that I have felt personally

has helped me navigate this
story is the fact in 2008

I actually wrote a
book about nature.

It's called Hot,
Flat, and Crowded.

And it is really
about our interaction

with the natural world,
globalization, and population.

And so a lot of people I got
to know in working on that book

have really been very
helpful teachers in this.

So one of them is
Rob Watson, who

founded Green Buildings for
the Natural Resources Defense
Council.

And Rob likes to say
that always remember,

Mother Nature is just
chemistry, biology, and physics.
That's all she is.
You can't talk her up.
You can't talk her down.

You can't say Mother Nature,
I'm tired of sitting at home,
or we're having a recession.

She's going to do whatever
chemistry, biology,
and physics dictate.

And she always bats last,
and she always bats 1,000.

Do not mess with
Mother Nature, OK?
So I start with that principle.

And then the second thing I'd
like to point out to people,

is the reason Trump
got in trouble
and was slow to respond--
there are many reasons.

And bashing Trump is
shooting fish in a barrel.

And I am not going to spend
a lot of time on that.

But there's one thing
that was really important
in his failure of leadership.

He thought if the market
was going up early on,

then he was succeeding
against Mother Nature.

Now, I'm a big believer
that the two largest

forces on the planet are the
market and Mother Nature,
Mother Nature and Father Greed.

But the market, at
the end of the day,

is no match for Mother
Nature because Mother Nature,

unlike the market, does
not start her day at 9:30.
She does not close at 4:00.

And she does not
take weekends off.

So while Trump-- actually,
we have to remember this.

It's one of the most remarkable
events in this story.

After his disastrous nationwide
speech and the market collapse,

and then the next day, he took
some steps and the markets

soared, I think, 2,000
points, he actually

autographed a chart of the
market's ascent that day

and sent it to Lou Dobbs
of Fox Business news.

And that knucklehead
played it on--

displayed it on
the evening news.

Now, while Trump and
Dobbs were doing that,

Mother Nature was silently,
inexorably, exponentially,

and mercilessly
spreading COVID-19
throughout our society.

So if you don't understand
her inexorable nature,

she is going to kill
you or someone you love.

There is only-- there are only
two ways to become immune--
a vaccine and herd immunity.

And if we don't respect that,
whether you're called VW,

or you're called New Zealand,
she will make you pay.

And so I have great
respect for her.

And one of the real misapplied
phrases in this thing
is we're at war.
We're at war.

And Trump says, I'm
a wartime president.

Well, when you're fighting
another collection

of human beings--
when we were at war

with the Nazis and
the Japanese, we

could out manufacture
and mobilize them.

When we were at war
with the Soviet Union,

we could out innovate
and out spend them.

But when you are "at
war" with Mother Nature,

there's only one way
to survive an encounter
with Mother Nature.

What she says is, it's not
the strongest who survived me.

It's not the smartest
who survived me.

It's the most
adaptive who survived.

That is the law of
natural selection.

And what she did give us, over
and above any other species,

she gave us a big
brain to figure out

how to adapt to her
climate changes.

And this is like
a climate change.

And if we don't
use that big brain

to adapt in a very strategic
and coordinated way--

because when you're
up against her,

if you are not humble, if
you are not coordinated--

because her virus will find
any crack and any opening.

And if you are not utterly
about chemistry, biology,

and physics, because
that's all she's about,

she will absolutely kill
you or someone you love.
ADI IGNATIUS: So let me go to--

we have a bunch of audience
questions coming in.

Let me go to one that really
relates directly to what
you were just talking about.

This is from Sophia
in Los Angeles.

And her question is, "is
herd immunity realistic?

Isn't the virus
constantly mutating?"

THOMAS FRIEDMAN: No, not
so far, not to a degree

that we have seen so
far like seasonal flus.

And there is a difference
between drift and shift

in terms of mutation that
epidemiologists talk about--

epigenetic drift
and epidemic shift.

And so so far, we
haven't seen evidence

of that suggested
herd immunity is not

possible with this
season's coronavirus.
JOSHUA MACHT: Interesting.

You know, one other
thing, Thomas,
you talk about the environment.

It is interesting
that right now, we're

almost giving the environment
a little bit of a breather.
We're not planting in any field.
We're not moving.
And people talk about it.
People talk about it.

I'm an allergy sufferer,
air pollutants things

like that that bother me, that
maybe I feel like, huh, it's
interesting right now.

I mean, are there
things out of this

that, maybe are good about
that that we could even
carry forward?

THOMAS FRIEDMAN:
Well, I think it's
a really good question, Josh.

This is, of course, the
warm-up act for the big one.

And the big one's
climate change.

And there are two differences
between a pandemic and climate
change.

The first is climate
change doesn't peak.

So if the north-- if
the Greenland Iceland--

if the Greenland ice shelf
melts, and the Arctic ice
shelf melts, they're gone.

They will no longer
reflect the sun's rays.
The oceans will rise.

They will be permanently
boiled by the Sun.

And the second difference
between pandemics and climate

change is there is no herd
immunity to climate change.

There's just a relentless
pounding on the herd.

So if this isn't a wake-up call
to what is now a decade where

we have to do everything we
can to stay under 2 degrees

rise average
temperature by 2100,

if we have any hope of managing
what is now unavoidable

and avoiding what
will be unmanageable--

if this isn't a
wake-up for that,
I really don't know what is.

And one of these you see,
Josh, too, we've seen all--

how minorities, particularly
African-Americans

in our country, have suffered
woefully disproportionately,
from COVID-19.
And one reason is--

and there's been a lot
of work done on this.

Their neighborhoods are where
people put power plants.,

where they slice
highways through.

And they're affected by
a lot of these breathing

asthmatic diseases,
particularly childhood asthma,

more than the general
population in proportion.
ADI IGNATIUS: All right.
I got another audience question.
This is Heidi in Seattle.
Hello, Heidi in Seattle.

So we put you on the
spot already as--

I mean, you're foreign
affairs correspondent.

We put you on the spot
as a science expert,

as a health expert, as a
domestic policy expert,
and you do it all well.

So now you're a
business futurologist.

"What will the new normal
look like, let's say,
six months from now?"

THOMAS FRIEDMAN: Well,
it's a good timeline
for the question, Adi.
Because, who knows?

There's the potential
here for, obviously,

a black swan of a cure, a
therapy, or actually a vaccine
coming earlier.

That would change,
obviously, everything.

But let's assume that the
predictions are right,

that it will take 12
to 18 months at best
to really have a vaccine.

The way I talk to--
think about it--

because again, we're
opening a museum,
so we're thinking about this?

What is a museum in the
post-lockdown world?

Because there is a feeling
out there like now,

I've got a broken leg, but
then, as soon as this is over,

I'm going to run the
sprint and relay again.
No, no, no.

You're going to go
from broken leg economy
to a crutches economy.

That is, whatever
business you're

in that serves the
public, you have

to imagine-- we're thinking
about this for our museum.

What is a museum like
when everyone who comes in

will be wearing a
mask, wearing gloves,
and have to stay 6 feet apart?

That is true whether
you're that VW plant.

That's true whether
you're in a restaurant.
True whether you're at HBR.

And so that's what I call
the crutches economy.

And man, I'm glad the
stock market's going up.

I'd rather see that
than it going down.
But it's 15% below its highs.

And I think it was Howard
Marks who said the other day,

the economy is not
15% off its high.
So there's some mismatch here.

And I realize the stock
market's looking ahead.

But man, that's got
really good vision
if it's seeing what it's seeing.

But maybe it's betting
on a cure or therapy.
I'm not a market prognosticator.
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

JOSHUA MACHT: Something does
feel really out of whack.
I'm curious.

Adi you and I talked a
little bit ahead of time

about asking you about strengths
and weaknesses of our response.
And it makes me--

I mean, I think we can see a
lot of weaknesses, especially

around the fact that
we're just not federally

coordinated the
way we need to be.
Do you see strengths of--

or pockets of it at least
of what we're doing,

or glimmers of hope, I guess
I might be looking for.

THOMAS FRIEDMAN:
Yeah, My macro view,

Josh, is that I wrote a
book with Michael Mandelbaum

in 2011, called
That Used to be Us,

How America Lost its Way
in the World It Invented
and How We Can Come Back.

And it was a book about the
fact that we can only be dumb
as we want to be for so long.

And the fact is that when
a pandemic hits like this,

it tells you a lot
about your immunity.

It tells you about a lot about
the level of social trust
in your community.

I live in a community
that seems to have

a high level social trust
here in Montgomery County.

We've had a lot of
good leadership.

It tells you about your--
what my friend Marina Garbus
calls your cognitive immunity.

And I think one of the things
that's really damaged America

in the last decade,
thanks to Rupert Murdoch,

and Fox News, and
social networks,

is our cognitive
immunity, our ability

to sort out fact and
fiction [AUDIO OUT] also.

And when you're up against
a scientific challenge,

and having a president
who labels anything

he doesn't like fake news, our
cognitive immunity as a society

has been seriously damaged and
at the worst possible time,

when we're up against
a scientific challenge.

And, at the same time,
our immunity to nature

has been challenged, because
where did this virus come from?

It comes from the fact that we
have had a reckless development

and urbanization that has
destroyed ecosystems, that

has killed the apex predators
in these ecosystems, that

has killed the iconic species
and left behind, what?

The generalized species
that can survive in
destroyed ecosystems.

And they're called bats,
rats, and primates.

And then we have
societies and cultures--
and Adi lived in one--

that likes to eat some of this
wildlife and hunt some of it

for medicinal purposes, for
sexual purposes, rhino horns,
you know.

That's why god
invented Viagra, OK?
Lay off the rhinos, OK?
But they hunt these wildlife.

They mix them together
in wet markets.

And we get all these
zoonotic diseases--

SARS, MERS, and now, COVID-19,
because they jump from these

animals that developed and
learned to live with these

viruses in their
natural habitat--
they co-evolved with them.

But once we take them out,
put them together with humans,
they jump.

So this is not going to
stop, unless those practices
of wet markets stop.

But also, that we don't
think about protecting

the ecosystems and
their natural predators

to these bats, and
rats, and primates
that can kill us in this world.
ADI IGNATIUS: So let me do--

Let's do one more
audience question.

And then, Tom, I think
we'll let you off the hook.

So this is from Scott from
Emeryville, California.

And it really tracks the
question I was going to ask,

which is really, how
has the world changed?

How is the world likely to
change, in a lasting way,

in terms of global
interdependence?

As COVID-19 accelerated
what we were already

seeing in terms of nationalism,
protectionism, xenophobia,

Is the world-- to
use your term, is
the world a little less flat?
THOMAS FRIEDMAN: Yes.

So I both laugh and cry when
people ask me that question.

I laugh because
tomorrow, I'm going

to be doing webinars with people
in India, people in China,
and with the UN.

People say, hey,
Friedman, I guess
the world isn't flat anymore.

And I just want
to say, excuse me?
